title: 103_hr4223
content: The Act is titled the "Voter Turnout Enhancement Study Commission Act". Congressional findings are included in the Act. The Congress recognizes the fundamental right to vote and the duty of governments to promote voting. The Act highlights the limited interaction most Americans have with their government through tax filing and voting. It also notes the disparity between the number of tax returns filed and votes cast in elections. Tying individuals' voting rights to their tax obligations can encourage participation in elections and scrutiny of government policies. The Voter Turnout Enhancement Study Commission is established by this Act, referred to as the "Commission". The membership details are outlined in Section 4. The Commission, composed of 9 members appointed by the President, Senate pro tempore, and Speaker of the House, must have no more than 2 members of the same political party per subsection. Members must be appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment and serve for the Commission's duration. The Commission, consisting of 9 members appointed by various officials, must have no more than 2 members from the same political party. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members serve without pay but are entitled to travel expenses. A majority of members constitutes a quorum, and a lesser number can hold a hearing. The Commission selects a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from its members. Meetings are held at the call of the Commission. The Commission, with 9 members appointed by officials, meets at the call of the Chairperson or majority. Initial meeting within 30 days of all appointments. The Commission is tasked with conducting a study on changing the filing date for Federal income tax returns to the 1st Tuesday after the 1st Monday in November. This study includes analyzing the costs and benefits of the change and the potential impact on voter participation in elections. The Commission is required to consult with various officials and entities in the process. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information, use the United States mails, and request official information from Federal agencies to carry out its duties. Members and agents of the Commission are authorized to take actions on behalf of the Commission. Additionally, the Commission can receive staff assistance from Federal agencies. The Commission can receive staff assistance from Federal agencies upon request. A report must be submitted to the President and Congress within 1 year of the Act's enactment, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation. The Commission will terminate upon submitting the report. Authorization of appropriations is also included. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS: Such sums as necessary for carrying out the Act can be appropriated.
